Interesting topic, but in my opinion, Java is too simple a language
(syntac=
tically anyway) to lend itself to "programming gems".

While it's indeed po=
ssible to see 20-line snippets in C, C++ or Perl that
might make you go "wo=
w, pretty", I don't think we can achieve this in Java
because its syntax is=
 so regular and clear (Generics excepted :-)).

Therefore, a Java test gem =
can only be observed at a more "macro" level:
involving a few classes, maki=
ng clever use of inheritance and other Java
mechanisms, showing a set of te=
st classes that are easy to read, maintain
and extend by future programmers=
, or sets of methods that represent a
"minimal spanning test tree" of test =
classes (as few test classes as you can
to entirely test a certain function=
ality of your code), etc...

-- 
C=E9dric

On 11/27/06, albsavoia <albsavoi=
a@...> wrote:
>
>
> I have been invited to contribute an article =
for a book that covers
> examples of beautiful code (those of you who have =
been programming for
> quite a while might remember the great book "Program=
ming Pearls" -
> this is along the same lines.)  The "catch" is that I have=
 to
> contribute testing-related examples - in other words: beautiful test
=
> code.
>
> I already have some ideas of what to cover, but I thought some =
of the
> people in this group might have some examples of tests that they
>=
 consider particularly "beautiful" or clever in their approach.
>
> I think=
 it's great that developer testing has reached the point that
> some author=
s/editors thought of including testing in such a book, and
> I want to make=
 sure I pick the best possible example(s) to pick from.
>
> Thanks,
>
> Alb=
